companySnapshot.auditorNote: Analysis based on Source Document 'NLTS-PR FS 12 31 2024 Rev156-1' as the closest available version to the requested 'Rev156-3'.

ratioCategories.description: Measures the company's ability to cover short-term obligations with current assets.

ratios.name: Current Ratio
ratios.interpretation: At 2.01, the company has $2.01 in assets for every $1.00 of liabilities, indicating a strong capability to meet short-term obligations [1].

ratios.name: Quick Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The ratio of 0.63 reveals a heavy reliance on inventory to pay debts. Excluding inventory ($1.34M), liquid assets are insufficient to cover current liabilities ($978k) [1].

ratios.name: Cash Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Cash reserves ($155k) cover only 16% of current liabilities, suggesting tight cash management typical of capital-intensive dealerships [2][3].

ratios.name: Working Capital
ratios.interpretation: Positive working capital of nearly $1M indicates operational stability, though much is tied up in inventory [4].

ratioCategories.description: Evaluates the company's ability to generate earnings relative to revenue and assets.

ratios.name: Gross Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Margin of 22.73% is slightly below industry averages for equipment dealers, potentially due to high COGS ($3.5M) or competitive pricing pressures [5].

ratios.name: Operating Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Strong operating efficiency; operating profit of $842k represents a healthy 18.56% of sales, indicating good control over OPEX [5].

ratios.name: Net Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Net margin of 9.32% is robust for the distribution sector, driven by an effective tax rate management and controlled interest expenses [5].

ratios.name: Return on Assets (ROA)
ratios.interpretation: Efficient use of asset base; generating $0.21 of net income for every dollar of assets is highly efficient [3][6].

ratios.name: Return on Equity (ROE)
ratios.interpretation: Exceptionally high ROE driven by high leverage (equity base is only $532k vs $1.97M assets) [7][8].

ratioCategories.description: Measures the extent to which the company uses debt to finance its operations.

ratios.name: Debt-to-Equity Ratio
ratios.interpretation: High leverage ratio of 2.70 indicates aggressive financing, primarily due to Floorplan financing ($439k) and Payables [1].

ratios.name: Debt-to-Assets Ratio
ratios.interpretation: 73% of assets are financed by creditors, highlighting significant solvency risk if cash flow tightens [3][7].

ratios.name: Interest Coverage Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Very safe coverage; operating income covers interest expense nearly 12 times over [9].

ratioCategories.description: Analyzes how effectively the company uses its assets and manages liabilities.

ratios.name: Asset Turnover
ratios.interpretation: The company generates $2.30 in sales for every dollar of assets, showing solid asset utilization [8].

ratios.name: Inventory Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Low turnover (2.61x) implies inventory is held for ~140 days. This suggests slow-moving stock or potential overstocking of equipment [10].

ratios.name: Days Sales Outstanding (DSO)
ratios.interpretation: Collection period of ~37 days is efficient and better than the standard 45-day benchmark, aiding liquidity [10].

ratios.name: Days Payable Outstanding (DPO)
ratios.interpretation: Taking ~49 days to pay vendors helps cash flow but may strain supplier relationships if terms are strictly 30 days [11].

ratioCategories.description: Based on limited available cash flow data in source documents.

ratios.name: Operating Cash Flow Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Insufficient Data: The specific 'Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities' figure is not fully legible/available in the provided source extracts for Rev156-1. Estimates suggest potential negative or low OCF due to inventory build-up.

overallAnalysis: Based on Source NLTS-PR FS 12 31 2024 Rev156-1 [1-13], National Lift Truck Service of PR demonstrates strong profitability (Net Margin 9.32%) and efficiency in collections (DSO 37 days). However, the company operates with high leverage (Debt/Equity 2.70) and significant inventory lock-up (140 days to sell). While short-term liquidity appears adequate (Current Ratio 2.01), the Quick Ratio of 0.63 highlights that solvency is heavily dependent on the ability to liquidate inventory. The high ROE (79.5%) is largely a function of the low equity base relative to debt.
